options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Developed my understanding of memorialization and digital memorialization. We also discussed many of the sub-topics within this rapidly growing field, such as holograms, video games, and digital artwork.  Additionally, these sub-topics would be explained or analyzed with regards to some mass atrocity, which meant that we also delved into the history of certain mass atrocities, with a slight emphasis on the Cambodian Genocide, Rwandan Genocide, and the Holocaust (although many other mass atrocities were discussed as well).
I learned more about the nature of digital memorialization and some implications of the act of digital memorialization.

I learned about digital memorialization in general and about digital memorialization of mass atrocities. We looked at several different websites and social media pages, heard from guest speakers, and discussed readings on designing and thinking about memorialization in the digital sphere.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The course was very interesting (the material and books were honestly fascinating and a pleasure to read). The discussions were also lively and engaging, so the seminar went by very fast. The diversity in topics was also fascinating; the blend of political science and anthropology was super cool. The guest speakers were also fascinating to listen to and talk with! 
Weaknesses: This course felt very disorganized at moments. Assignments were constantly being changed (instructions were contradictory, etc)
and readings were switched on short notice (which made it hard to deal with the assignments). Additionally, the class time wasn't well divided, so we would often briefly skim certain readings or run out of time.
I liked the readings that we had to do and the papers were manageable as well.

A lot of the time, we weren't able to discuss all the readings and instructions for what the professors were looking for in terms of grading for response essays and presentations was relatively unclear. Some of the content was very interesting and the class would have great discussions.

I think that this class was very focused on the topic, which was great! Although I do think one area of improvement could be better communication about the response papers/what was expected of us for them. I really enjoyed the readings and the student presentations on them. The discussions were interesting and I appreciated the digitally interactive nature of the course which worked well on zoom.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course worked really well online because it was focused on digital learning in general! I really appreciated the in person session prof. Simon and Zucker hosted as well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course; it was super interesting and very engaging! The one thing I would say is to maybe keep in mind that certain elements of the course are very much a "work-in-progress," which can be quite frustrating when you're just trying to do your coursework. That being said, I still enjoyed this seminar. If you're interested in learning about genocide or mass atrocities and memorialization, I would say take it. Just know that this is very much not a classic poli sci class.
Yes, if you're interested in the subject, take the class! The assignments aren't demanding as well!

I would, but only if youre genuinely interested in the topic. It felt like there was a lot of material to be covered but its a very focused course on digital memorialization. We focused less on learning about the mass atrocities behind the memorials and more on the memorials themselves (and the idea of memorialization.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We also had two in-person seminars.
Towards the end of the year, there were some in-person seminars
We met in person twice which was great, except the second was a hybrid version that didnt work too well for online students.
